text:
Well, Dean Datar, Dean
Weinzierl, Sabha, Zoe,

and the full SA team, members
of the faculty, proud parents,

and, of course,
fellow graduates,

I've seen you all use
these words so many times

before that they've absolutely
lost all meaning to me.

But nevertheless, I am
truly humbled and honored

to be addressing the
HBS class of 2023.
[CHEERING]

To our friends and family,
those present and those
who could not be, thank you.

We are, as Lord
Byron reminds us,
a part of all who we have met.
That's you.
You are the reason we smile.
You're the reason that we laugh.

You're the reason that
we chase our dreams,

and you are the
reason that we believe

that we can be the leaders who
make a difference in the world.
To our partners, thank you.
You love us unconditionally.
And by God, you've proved it.
You've definitely proved it.

You indulged our need to tell
you about the complex process

flows and the production
control system
at a cranberry receiving plant.

You dealt with our hectic
schedules and our many late

nights studying at any of
our campus' many libraries,

The Grand, Encore,
Felipe's, La Fabrica.
You make us great.

You make us happy,
and we love you.
To our professors, thank you.

You are giants in your
fields, and you treated us
like colleagues and friends.

Personally, I've learned
more about business, people,

facilitation, good questions,
and listening in the past 2

years than I have
in the past 10.

We owe you a debt of gratitude
and, perhaps, an advance

on the Executive Education
course we'll eventually take.

To the staff that keeps
this place running,

those in Spangler Kitchen,
at Student Academic Services,

our janitorial team, and
board washers, our OLFs,

and our scribes, thank you
for making this place--
thank you.
[CHEERING]

--for making this place
so much more than a school
and for making it a home.

And of course, I'd be remiss
to not give a shout out

to my discussion group,
to my Evolve group,

and to the elegant,
to the electric,
to the epic section E.
[CHEERING]

To all, welcome to
Harvard Business School.

Some of our professors call it
the West Point of capitalism.

Some of our professors call it
the place for the development
of principled leaders.

And all of my classmates
call it, oh, I
go to business school in Boston.

When we applied
to HBS, our world

was in the depths of
a global pandemic.

Our lives were put on
pause in a world where
we lost so many and so much.

We were not yet
vaccinated, and we did not

know what normal
was about to become.
Still, we dared to dream.

This class has not taken
this experience for granted.

When we arrived, our COVID
testing and masking in classes

did not deter us from
friendship and connection.

This class has valued every
unmasked smile, every hug,
and every handshake.

We have valued the
ability to learn

from each other in the classroom
and laugh with each other
at the HBS show.

We've also learned a
great many things here,

although I've had to convince
family members of this.

Financial modeling, blockbuster
strategy, the five forces

in the value bar, the
diamond square framework,

and most importantly, how to
manufacture circuit boards
in Shad.

But this school has
taught us something else

relentlessly, both inside
the classroom and out.

It has taught us that
success is not only measured

by the money in our bank
account, although most of mine

is loans, or the number of
international trips we took,

or the power we
attain in our careers.

It is best measured by
the way we treat and care

for those around us,
by the compassion
that we show for others.

I want to tell you why this
lesson resonates with me.

My mother sold horchata
at the local church
with my grandmother.

My father worked the fields
with his brothers and sisters

and lived in a small house with
dirt floors and a tin roof.

They did not have
much to begin with.

Most nights, my grandmother
could only offer her children

a dinner of tortillas y
limon, tortillas and a splash

of lemon, before
they went to bed.

They both dropped out of the
equivalent of middle school
to help their families survive.

Their stories might
have been simple.

They might have
worked the fields,

gone to church on Sundays, and
raised a family, surrounded

by the love and support of their
community, but they did not.
They could not.

The Salvadoran Civil
War claimed the lives

of some of their family
members, their friends,
and almost claimed theirs.

My mom and dad fled
to a new country

with a different language,
a different culture,

and with no hope of seeing
their families anytime soon.

In the United States, my
mother was a housekeeper

in the Hollywood
Hills, and my father

worked on the factory floor
of an airplane brake company.

They are exactly the
kind of individuals

that I implore you to
support and have compassion
for in your daily lives.

My family had a
priest who went out

of his way to support
immigrants fleeing violence

and help my parents
become citizens.

We had an accomplished
engineer, who

took my father under his wing,
mentored him, and recognized
his potential.

We had a local bank manager
who helped my dad secure

a mortgage, even though he
did not understand the US
financial system.

My goal in life is to be a
multiplier for their kindness,
for their compassion.

But as hard as my
parents worked,

they and their community
alone could not
have made my story possible.

My mother-- and I'm
not making this up--

sent me to every single
day of kindergarten

wearing an ironed, white dress
shirt and a black, clip-on bow
tie.

While I quickly convinced
my mom that this was not

the cool thing to
do, I struggled

to learn my first English
words in second grade.

I read voraciously
at the local library,

five blocks away from our
home, checked out as many books

as the librarians
would allow, and I

would carry these bags
of books back and forth.

You see, while I was reading my
books at the dining room table,

my dad would sometimes
sit with me, poring over

electricity and gas bills
with a look of concern

that even a young child could
read, never admitting to me

that the change we made
from recycling our aluminum

cans that week helped
pay for groceries.

I may have been a
child, but I was

a translator for my
mother's doctors,

the filler of job
applications, the navigator

of a difficult
health care system.

I grew up with Harry Potter,
and Pokemon, and Jack Bauer,

but I also grew up knowing how
much money was in my dad's bank

account and that it would never
be enough to pay for college.

I became obsessive about
doing well in school,

being the best in the
classroom and the track.

I sought out every opportunity
I could and latched on
for dear life.

Education was the only tool
for social mobility I had,
and I was determined to hold on.
And hold on, I did.

I like to tell people
that I didn't cry
when I was accepted to college.

I cried when I realized what
the financial aid packages were.

I packed my bags, and I headed
East to start my freshman

fall in Harvard Yard, a
place that represented
my ancestors' wildest dreams.

I would not be here
today without my parents,

without all of my
teachers, without

an educational nonprofit
that supported me,

without a professor
who championed me,

and without the countless
managers who believed
in me enough to mentor me.

Being kind, practicing
compassion, creating community,

these are actions,
not aesthetics.

We don't need CEOs
that know what to say,

but rather leaders
with a conscience
and a penchant for doing good.

As a class that is
truly global, we

are meant to be global
opportunity creators,

global innovators, and global
amplifiers for the greatness
of those around us.

We are meant to
not just contribute

to the social and economic
structures of society,

but to change and challenge
them, to improve and re-imagine

them until they reflect our
highest dreams and aspirations.

And already, many
of us are doing so.

Our friends and classmates
are leading from the front,
standing at the helm.

Kathryn Webster, who
has led a nonprofit

to support blind
young professionals,

called Together
Achieving Dreams,
a tribute to her father, Tad.

Jerome Fulton Jr., who
founded the Angel B. Wilson

Foundation to help
Miami youth affected

by gun violence, a tribute
to his mother, who was,
herself, a victim of it.

David Velasquez, an
MD/MPP/MBA in our class

who has served on the
legislative committee

of the Massachusetts
Medical Society

and advocated for
marginalized communities

through his writings
in The Boston Globe.

These are just a few of the
many change makers in our class.

But in spite of
what we've learned

about scarcity and
finite resources,

there is no limit to the supply
of kindness and compassion.
But we can invest in them.

If we choose to practice
kindness and compassion

every year, every month,
every week, every single day,

they will grow in yourself, in
your family, in your friends,
and in your communities.

You can be the responsible
stewards of a teacher's pension
in California.

You can make the movies that
inspire social change, halfway
across the globe.

You can fuel the engine
of innovation that
fights illness and disease.

You can be the mentors that
make diversity and equity
a reality instead of a goal.

You can create a world that
is better for my children

and for yours, a world that
considers workers' dignity as

much as consumer delight, a
world where profits coexist
with humanity.

It gives me, and it should
give the world, great hope

to know that no matter
the economic, social,

or political
circumstances we face,

we will be able to lean on each
other, this group of people,
this community.

We have our summer
plans, our plane tickets,
and moving vans booked.

We have a well of memories
that will never run dry,

and we have the
friendships that filled it.

The only question now is, after
two years at Harvard Business

School, what kind of
leader will you be?
Thank you, everyone.
[CHEERING]
